Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Power efficient design of wireless networks with delay guarantees

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The growth of mobile devices has been phenomenal in the last few years. Despite the recent improvements in battery technologies, future applications and data rate requirements will drive mobile devices to be power hungry and put a severe strain on the scarce battery resource. In contrast to advances in the semiconductor industry, which follows Moore's Law, battery technology has advanced at a much slower pace. With the growing advent of high data rate mobile multimedia applications, color LCD displays, GPS and faster processors, the demand on battery energy becomes more intense. Thus, power efficiency is a critical
requirement of future mobile devices.

This research involves the study and design of power efficient wireless networks with Quality of service guarantees. Specific focus is on design of physical layer coding, modulation and power control in conjunction
with MAC layer scheduling algorithms. The investigators study a unified framework for multiuser and multihop networks. Fundamental bounds on power required in mobile networks are derived to provide finite delay guarantees on the multimedia traffic. The investigators use a cross disciplinary approach incorporating ideas from traditional communications theory, queuing theory, signal processing and network design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The growth of wireless  communication devices has been exceptional over the last few years. Traditional communication systems use a layered design approach in which the implementation of each layer is independent of the other layers. This approach is one of the reasons for the success and rapid growth of the Internet. This layered design philosophy when applied to the design of high speed wireless data networks leads to severe limitations on performance. These limitations are primarily because of the lack of ability of the higher layers of the protocol stack to efficiently adapt to the wide variations in the wireless channel quality.

The goal of this project is to study cross-layer designs for multimedia wireless networks. Specifically, optimizing the limited battery resources at a mobile node is the primary metric of this work. Further, to support multimedia applications, packet delay has been incorporated as a constraint in the physical layer coding, modulation and power control design.

In this project, several adaptive and smart packet scheduling and transmission strategies are proposed. The main result of this project is that using the proposed adaptive transmission strategies can lead to an order of magnitude reduction in the power required to transmit the data.This work also provides a unified theoretical framework to understand some of the practical limitations in the knowledge of time varying traffic conditions and channel variations. Specifically, practical low complexity schedulers that do not require any apriori knowledge of time varying traffic conditions and adaptively learn the statistics of the traffic are developed and shown to achieve near optimal performance in certain cases.

This project also proposes a novel feed-forward and feedback scheme that exchanges a few bits of information between the transmitter and receiver and show that this results in huge reductions in the packet loss ratios over time varying wireless channels. This new feed-forward transmission strategy could lead to an entire new theory analogous to the theory of channel state information at the transmitter.

The results of this project can impact a wide range of next generation wireless systems such as LTE and WiMAX. This project also leads to closer interactions between different fields such as queueing, signal processing and communication theories. The student who were trained as part of this project are well equipped to investigate challenging problems in this crucial interdisciplinary area.
